awd_titl_txt: SpecEES: Collaborative Research: Energy Efficient Dynamic Spectrum Access in Uncoordinated Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
With its focus on energy efficient dynamic spectrum access where the users are treated as equals and there is minimal coordination across the users, this project addresses challenges for enabling next-generation wireless communications and networking in a dynamic spectrum environment. The results from the project should greatly enhance access to broadband wireless services in traditionally under-serviced communities. The spectrum-sensing and spectrum-sharing techniques developed should prove to be equally applicable in a slew of applications involving energy-constrained ad hoc networks such as those encountered in disaster relief operations and in a variety of applications relevant to national security. The involvement of undergraduate students in this project, especially in software radio experiment, is expected to foster their long-term interest in Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM)-related fields.

This research project is focused on both spectral efficiency and energy efficiency for a class of dynamic spectrum access applications that have been much less well studied: an uncoordinated wide-band system where the users are treated as equals, i.e., there is no primary/secondary distinction. The project will develop the spectrum management framework as well as enabling technologies for such applications, ranging from multi-channel spectrum sensing using quickest change detection to novel spectrum access schemes for spectral/energy efficient and fair spectrum usage in the absence of user coordination. Experimental studies are an integral part of the proposed research, and the project leverages existing software radio capabilities developed at Syracuse University. This study of spectrum access with equally privileged users without coordination also fills an important gap in dynamic spectrum access. Given the generality of the models considered, this research can be expected to make fundamental contributions to the theories of quickest change detection and random access.

por.por_cntn:
With its focus on energy efficient dynamic spectrum access where the users are treated as equals and there is minimal coordination across the users, this project addressed some of the challenges for enabling next-generation wireless communications and networking in a dynamic spectrum environment. PI Veeravalli and his graduate students at Illinois focussed primarily on applying techniques from multi-armed bandit theory to develop algorithms for uncoordinated dynamic spectrum access.

Research topics explored in the project have included: (1) Analysis of the degrees of freedom in wireless interference networks with cooperative transmission and backhaul load constraints; (2) Design of a heterogeneous cellular network with a wireless backhaul; (3) Design of dynamic spectrum access algorithms using stochastic multi-user bandits; (4) Design of algorithms for decentralized heterogeneous multi-player multi-armed bandits with non-zero rewards on collision; and (5) Adversarial multi-user multi-armed bandits for uncoordinated spectrum access.

Educational activities have included: (1) Proceedings papers and presentations (including invited and plenary talks) on the above research topics at IEEE ICASSP, IEEE ICNC, and IEEE Asilomar conferences;  (2) Development of course material related to interference management for graduate course ECE 562: Advanced Digital Communication, at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign; (3) Completing a book with A. El Gamal on Interference Management in Wireless Networks, which was published by Cambridge University Press in 2018.

Collaboration activities have included: (1) Visits by PI V. Veeravalli to Syracuse University in October 2017 and October 2019 to collaborate with Prof. Biao Chen, who is the PI at Syracuse University for this collaborative project; (2) Implementation of the algorithms developed by PI Veeravalli and his students at Illinois on a testbed developed by Prof. Biao Chen and his student at Syracuse; (3) Regular Skype teleconference meetings between the researchers at the two universities.

This project provides a solid foundation for extensive training of graduate students participating in the research. This project requires and calls for a unique combination of high-level information-theoretic, statistical inference and optimization skills, as well an understanding of the practical constraints in wireless networks, specifically those that involve uncoordinated spectrum access. 

Research on interference management, coordination and related resource allocation will advance our understanding of how to significantly improve the energy and spectral efficiency of the evolving wireless networks, especially those with uncoordinated spectrum access. While the goal of this project was to advance the science and engineering of wireless networking, it could potentially have impact on the national and international wireless industry through the development of new design principles and methodologies for the design and implementation of future wireless networks. By enabling more efficient use of wireless spectrum, such networks have the potential to improve broadband access across the world and provide the communication infrastructure for numerous new wireless services.
